Title: A Summer Spectacle Where Fireflies Are the Guiding Light
Abstrace: Bill and Mary-Ellen McDonald host firefly viewing parties, hoping to inspire their neighbors to stop using pesticides and consider rewilding their lawns.

Title: Holiday Fireworks Worsen Air Quality Nationwide
Abstrace: Seattle, New York City and Los Angeles were among the places with high air quality indexes after fireworks celebrations.

Title: Reducing Pollution a Boat at a Time
Abstrace: Editorial praises Environmental Protection Agency for approving no-discharge zone which bans vessels from dumping treated or untreated waste in Long Island Sound from Groton to Guilford, Conn; calls for similar ban from Guilford to New York border

Title: Reducing Pollution a Boat at a Time
Abstrace: If Connecticut can help reduce even small amounts of pollution in the Long Island Sound, there is no reason not to do so.

Title: POLLUTION ISSUE RAISED AT AMERICAN ELECTRIC'S MEETING
Abstrace: Shareholder resolution urging American Electric Power Co to do more to disclose and reduce its emissions of global-warming gases and air pollution wins 26.9 percent of votes at company's annual shareholders meeting; resolution, filed by Connecticut pension fund and Christian Brothers Investment Services Inc, asks company to disclose how its profitability could be hurt by company's status as major emitter (S)

Title: Sewage Plant Trading Program Reducing Pollution
Abstrace: SINCE 2002, Connecticut has reduced the amount of nitrogen being released into the Long Island Sound by allowing its 79 sewage-treatment plants to trade pollution credits.

Title: States Planning Own Lawsuits Over Pollution
Abstrace: Attorneys general of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut say they are ready to force power plants to make billions of dollars of pollution-control improvements now that Environmental Protection Agency has decided to drop investigations at old coal-fired plants, a major source of air pollution that drifts over Northeast; caution that states have far fewer resources than federal government to battle one of nation's most powerful industries and that they will have to focus their actions against fewer utilities; photos of Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal, Democrat, and New York Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer, Democrat (L)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Norwalk: Law To Reduce Pollution
Abstrace: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland signs legislation to force six of state's power plants to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hamden: Pollution Cleanup Ordered
Abstrace: Connecticut State Department of Environmental Protection orders town of Hamden and three other entities to clean up polluted soil in neighborhood of Hamden Middle School (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Record Fine For Pollution
Abstrace: Tyco Printed Circuit Group is fined record $10 million for dumping lead-laced wastewater into sewer systems of Manchester, Stafford and Staffordville, Conn; $4 million of fine will go to sewer and wastewater improvement projects (S)

Title: New York and 3 Other States Join Against Air Pollution
Abstrace: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennslyvania sue Allegheny Energy Inc, claiming that company's coal-fired electric generating plants in Pennsylvania emit pollution that drifts across state lines, worsens smog, produces acid rain and causes respiratory problems for people in metropolitan region; want company to install antipollution equipment; company says it is not in violation of pollution laws (M)

Title: 9 Northeast States File Suit Over New Rules on Pollution
Abstrace: Nine Northastern states file legal challenge to new air-pollution rules for power plants and other industries just hours after Bush administration publishes rules; say rules constitute most serious effort at rolling back landmark Clean Air Act since it was enacted more than 30 years ago; changes would allow thousands of aging coal-fired power plants and other industrial sites to upgrade without having to install costly anti-pollution devices (M)

Title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 States Seek Pollution Controls
Abstrace: New York and Connecticut file lawsuit calling on Environmental Protection Agency to issue stricter national standards to limit storm water seeping from construction sites; suit asserts that other states have unfair advantage over New York and Connecticut, which have strict laws (S)

Title: Eastern States Introduce a Plan to Cap Tailpipe Pollution
Abstrace: Twelve states and the District of Columbia released a draft plan for an ambitious cap-and-trade program to curb planet-warming emissions on the region’s roads.

Title: States Sue E.P.A. Over Delayed Soot Rules
Abstrace: Eleven states argue that drafting new rules is vital to public health. But the Obama administration faces pressure from Republican critics who say that tighter air pollution rules could hurt the economy.

Title: Court Backs Most E.P.A. Action On Polluters in Central States
Abstrace: Federal appeals court, 3-0, mostly upholds Environmental Protection Agency crackdown on nitrogen oxide emissions from 392 Midwestern and Southern factories and power plants; sends two sections of rule back to EPA for more work; Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York and Pennsylvania sought crackdown on upwind polluters (M)

Title: Region's Air Doesn't Meet New Standards
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency finds that air in most areas of New York State and all of New Jersey and Connecticut does not meet federal air quality standards for smog; problem is caused by combination of dirty emissions from atuomobiles and factories in states themselves and contaminates floating in air from Midwest and central Canada; states must now act to reduce ground-level ozone; EPA says air is not dirtier, but standards are higher and more aggressive to make air cleaner and reduce asthma and other respiratory problems; map shows pollution in three states (M)

Title: 3 Northeast States Win Verdict Against a Utility
Abstrace: Judge Edmund A Sargus Jr rules that Ohio Edison violated Clean Air Act when it failed to install improved pollution controls at coal-burning power plant; ruling is major victory for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, which have joined EPA in lawsuits over acid rain; nitrogen oxides and sulfur dioxides emitted by some 70 such power plants in Ohio Valley are blamed for 80 percent to 90 percent of acid rain deposits in Adirondacks (M)

Title: Squaring Off on Global Warming
Abstrace: The state’s environmental groups and the Connecticut Business and Industry Association cannot afford to ignore each other.

Title: Our Air, Their Air: Most of It Is Bad
Abstrace: Article on air pollution in Connecticut, which has been ranked among top 10 states beset by smog problems in study by US Public Interest Research Group; Attorney General Richard Blumenthal, who has filed and threatens to file lawsuits against other states and cities, notes bad air knows no boundaries; efforts by state to clean up air described; photos (M)

Title: Utility to Spend $1.2 Billion to Cut Emissions
Abstrace: Dominion Virginia Power Co, in largest settlement ever under Clean Air Act, reaches accord with Environmental Protection Agency and five states to spend $1.2 billion to install pollution-reducing technology in eight coal-burning power plants in Virgina and West Virginia by 2013; New York, New Jersey and Connecticut have long complained that emissions from plants were polluting their air; company also agrees to pay $5.3 million in federal penalties and $14 million for various states' environmental projects; new controls will curb emissions of sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain, and nitrogen oxide, which causes smog; Admr Christie Whitman holds settlement shows Bush administration's commitment to fully enforcing environmental laws (M)

Title: Many Counties Failing Fine-Particle Air Rules
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency says about third of Americans live in counties that do not meet seven-year-old standards for microscopic particles of pollution that cause thousands of premature deaths every year; 20 states affected, including New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, have three years to develop plans to bring their problem counties into compliance by 2010, or face loss of federal highway money; map (M)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Emissions Testing To Resume
Abstrace: Connecticut will resume testing vehicles for emissions more than six months after program was suspended because of technical problems with tests conducted by Agbar Technologies (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: 2 Criticized Plants Set For Sale
Abstrace: Wisconsin Energy Corp says that it plans to

Title: National Briefing | Washington: 3 States Plan To Sue E.P.A.
Abstrace: Attorneys general of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Maine will sue EPA to force agency to restrict carbon dioxide as 'criteria pollutant' under terms of Clean Air Act (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Rowland To Decide On Air Bill
Abstrace: Connecticut Gov John G Rowland will announce whether he will sign into law or veto bill to tighten emissions standards on Connecticut's six most polluting coal- and oil-burning power plants (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: New Firm To Test Emissions
Abstrace: Connecticut Motor Vehicles Department will end contract with Envirotest Systems to award job to Agbar Technologies, which will bolster automotive emissions testing procedures and implement fraud prevention measures (M)

Title: State Is Investigating Emissions Testing Company
Abstrace: Connecticut State Sen Biagio Ciotto, co-chairman of Transportation Committee, is gathering as much information as possible before deciding fate of Connecticut's embattled emissions testing program; has held hearing in Hartford attended by numerous state agencies and Agbar Technologies, company contracted to run program; believes that fraud did occur at some of 279 dealers licensed to do emissions repairs and testing (S)

Title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Dredging Plan Criticized
Abstrace: Environmental groups in Suffolk County, NY, will sue to stop Environmental Protection Agency plan to deposit dredging wastes from Connecticut site into Long Island Sound (S)

Title: 2 States Break Rules on Smog, E.P.A. Finds
Abstrace: Environmental Protection Agency proposes designating all of New Jersey and Connecticut as being out of compliance with tougher anti-smog standards; also classifies Putnam, Orange and Dutchess counties in New York in same category with New York City, designation that could mean tougher standards there for industry, gas pumps and cars; state wanted counties placed in separate category; changes are intended to satisfy lawsuit brought by American Lung Association and environmental groups (M)

Title: Emissions Testing Gets The Green Light (Again)
Abstrace: Connecticut Motor Vehicles Department will resume tests of vehicle emissions, which had been suspended on April 22 because of computer software problems, on November 12 (S)

Title: Research Lab Falsified Tests On Toxins, Reports Say
Abstrace: Connecticut Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal releases report condemning procedures at University of Connecticut's Environmental Research Institute for falsifying test results for soil, water and air samples they analyzed for private, state and federal agencies; says sound scientific research and practices were abandoned for convenience (M)

Title: Rowland Seeks Votes for Veto But Will Sign Emissions Bill
Abstrace: Connecticut legislature passes bill that would require six of state's oldest and most polluting oil- and coal-burning power plants to meet current federal emissions standard by 2005; Gov John Rowland, who initially said he would sign measure into law, derides bill as bad public policy and now may veto it (M)

Title: Relief From the Roar of Traffic
Abstrace: When it comes to noise pollution, Connecticut has given the same answer for more than 15 years: it’s not a priority.

Title: D.M.V. Keeping Watch Of Emissions Testing
Abstrace: d.m.v. keeping

Title: Emissions Testing Program Is Facing Extended Delay
Abstrace: Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles, citing software problems of contractor Agbar Technologies, delays restart of emissions testing program until middle of August at earliest (S)

Title: An Aggressive Weed Grabs Hold in Greenwich
Abstrace: Connecticut Environmental Protection Deputy Commissioner David Leff raises concern about fast-growing Japanese weed, Polygonum perfoliatum, also known as mile-a-minute weed, that is proliferating in Greenwich (S)

Title: E.P.A. Sued Over Mercury in the Air
Abstrace: New Jersey and eight other states file lawsuit challenging Environmental Protection Agency rule that they claim does not do enough to control dangerous mercury emissions from coal-fired power plants (M)

Title: Terry Backer, 61, Legislator Who Helped Clean Up Long Island Sound
Abstrace: Mr. Backer, a 12-term state representative in Connecticut, played a major role in largely successful efforts to clean up one of the country’s biggest estuaries.

Title: In Talks of Nitrogen Reduction, Shore Communities Take Notice
Abstrace: Communities bordering Long Island Sound have spent hundreds of millions of dollars to reduce nitrogen in waste water, and some of them question New York City's commitment to agreement to do same; nitrogen can overstimulate organic activity in water, leading to algae blooms that eat up oxygen needed by animals and fish; photo (M)

Title: Another Step to Clean Up a River
Abstrace: Article on latest, and at cost of between $600 million and $650 million the most expensive, project to clean up Connecticut River and its tributaries; new plan calls for construction of separate pipes for storm water and sewage at Wethersfield Cove, with any sewage overflow running to newly expanded Hartford Pollution Control Authority plant; photos (M)

Title: The Winding Road Of Emissions Testing
Abstrace: Ray Garcia, lawyer for contractor Agbar Technologies, says company plans to test new software at 24 vehicle emissions testing stations in Connecticut by end of week; Federal Highway Administration has informed Gov M Jodi Rell that state could face sanctions on $240 million in funds if it does not meet clean air requirement because of lack of emissions testing (S)

Title: A Plan by Eastern States to Cap Tailpipe Emissions Gets Off to a Slow Start
Abstrace: Connecticut, Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Washington, D.C., all announced they would join a cap-and-trade program for cars and trucks. But many bigger states have yet to join.

Title: In Reversal, Rowland Vetoes Bill to Cut Emissions at 6 Power Plants
Abstrace: Gov John G Rowland vetoes bill that would have forced Connecticut's six oldest and least efficient power plants to cut emissions of smog-forming sulfur dioxide and end plants' ability buy federal emission credits from other, cleaner plants in Northeast; says bill, which he earlier said he would sign, would worsen state's air quality on smoggiest days and leave state open to California-style power shortages this summer; Democrats and environmentalists say veto show Rowland cares more about power-industry profits than clean air (M)

Title: Emissions Tests: The Upgraded Version
Abstrace: Update on status of Connecticut vehicle emissions testing program, whose software has been upgraded; Motor Vehicles Department spokesman Bill Seymour says no problems have been reported in first week and that number of calls to information phone line has declined; photo (M)

Title: New York City and 8 States Plan to Sue Power Plants
Abstrace: Eight states and New York City will file federal lawsuit demanding 'substantial cuts' in carbon dioxide emissions by five major utility companies that operate 174 power plants (M)

Title: Turn Down Those Lights!
Abstrace: Article on debate across Connecticut over Connecticut Light & Power's plan to upgrade street lighting in towns it serves; town officials say historic, rural character of towns will be destroyed; photos (M)

Title: Utility Shareholders Demand Liability Disclosure
Abstrace: Group of shareholders that includes Connecticut's treasurer's office, State of Connecticut Plans and Trust Fund and members of New York-based Interfaith Center on Corporate Responsibility begins campaign to compel largest electric utilities in nation to publish information about liabilities they might face because of their emission of gases that contribute to global warming; coalition files resolutions to be voted upon at annual meetings later this year of American Electric Power, Southern Co, Xcel Energy Inc, TXU Corp and Cinergy Corp (M)

Title: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: 3 States Sue E.P.A. to Regulate Emissions of Carbon Dioxide
Abstrace: Connecticut, Maine and Massachusetts sue Environmental Protection Agency, contending that carbon dioxide emissions from cars and power plants should be regulated as air pollutant because they contribute to global warming; officials say it is first time that any state has sued government to compel action on climate change (M)

Title: Mayors Seek Regional Plan on Power Plant Gas Emissions
Abstrace: The mayors of more than 40 cities in the Northeast have urged the governors of New York and eight other states to quickly adopt a regional plan to regulate greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming, saying in a letter yesterday that climate change ''poses significant threat to the people and communities of the Northeast.''      Officials in the nine states released a general outline of the plan, called the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. While state officials have given it preliminary approval, some specifics are still unresolved, especially those involving the eventual cost to consumers. They need to be ironed out before the plan can go back to the individual states for legislative or regulatory approval, a process that could begin early next year.

Title: The Sound's Intricate Web
Abstrace: In the end, what is good for lobster, cordgrass, river herring and flounder is good for the entire Long Island Sound.

Title: Two States Agree to Limit Dumping in the Sound
Abstrace: The states of New York and Connecticut do not always see eye to eye when it comes to managing the waters they share in Long Island Sound.     But the two states, along with federal environmental officials and the United States Army Corps of Engineers, found common ground yesterday and agreed to strictly limit, and eventually eliminate, the dumping of dredged material in the Sound.

Title: Firm Sues Connecticut Over Suspension of Auto Emissions Tests
Abstrace: Agbar Technologies, company hired to do auto emissions testing in Connecticut, sues Connecticut for suspending testing because of flaws in program that cause false readings; says suspension is illegal and based on premature and inaccurate audit; says it will face financial hardship since workers will be laid off and need to be retrained when problem is fixed (M)

Title: Don't Touch That Dial: Emissions Test in Progress
Abstrace: Sophisticated monitoring devices are being used to insure that Connecticut's new emissions testing program is fair and that techicians are held accountable; photo (M)

Title: Thinking Beyond Asphalt
Abstrace: The announcement that the state Department of Transportation plans to extend regional train service to sporting events is a good sign that the department is shifting its focus to mass transit.

Title: Saving the Sound
Abstrace: Editorial supports compromise plan developed by New York City officials, with help of environmental groups, that promises to meet goal of cutting nitrogen from sewage waste dumped into Long Island Sound by 58.5 percent at just over half original estimated cost

Title: The Sound's Intricate Web
Abstrace: Editorial supports more stringent lobster catch limits in Long Island Sound; holds Connecticut's Congressional delegation should insist that federal government help underwrite research into 1999 die-back; sees need for cooperation between New York and Connecticut to protect Sound and coastal salt marshes that support its intricate ecosystem

Title: Over Troubled Water
Abstrace: Editorial views latest Long Island Sound Study, conducted by partnership among US Environmental Protection Agency and government agencies and private groups in New York and Connecticut, as encouraging but cautionary

Title: Over Troubled Water
Abstrace: Editorial views latest Long Island Sound Study, conducted by partnership among US Environmental Protection Agency and government agencies and private groups in New York and Connecticut, as encouraging but cautionary

Title: Over Troubled Water
Abstrace: Editorial views latest Long Island Sound Study, conducted by partnership among US Environmental Protection Agency and government agencies and private groups in New York and Connecticut, as encouraging but cautionary

Title: Coast Guard Investigates Oil Spill
Abstrace: Coast Guard opens investigation to determine why barge carrying two million gallons of home heating oil from New York Harbor to Port Jefferson struck charted rock reef in Long Island Sound; Norwalk Harbormaster Michael Griffin says oil slick could have harmed shellfish beds and wetlands; photo (M)

Title: Study of Bridgeport Harbor Is Cited by Critics of L.I. Sound Dumping Plan
Abstrace: Sen Charles E Schumer of New York criticizes plan to dredge five Connecticut harbors and dump sludge into Long Island Sound; critics say new studies show that Bridgeport and other harbors are more polluted then earlier believed; Environmental Protection Agency says that any muck that is too contaminated will not be placed in Sound, but treated and disposed of on land; photo (M)

Title: 9 States in Plan to Cut Emissions by Power Plants
Abstrace: Nine Northeastern states reportedly reach preliminary agreement to freeze power plant emissions at current levels and then reduce them by ten percent by 2020; photo; first such cooperative action follows Bush administration not to regulate greenhouse gases and would require legislation in each state; initiative would set up market-driven system to control carbon dioxide emissions from more than 600 electric generators, and could spur action nationally; California, Washington and Oregon explore similar agreement; Northeast states were brought together by New York Gov George Pataki, who broke sharply with administration on issue; spokesman declines comment on leaked draft; environmentalists say region's carbon dioxide emissions are about those of Germany, but that real significance of accord is example for other states (M)

Title: So, How's the Weather? Futuristic; From Smog to Sun, Climate Scientists Zoom In on Changes
Abstrace: New York Climate and Health Project seeks to predict effects of global warming in region by 2050; divides 31 counties around city into hundreds of grid boxes and measures multitude of data from each; will identify 'heat islands' that can trap heat, making areas hotter; is experimenting with ways to make neighborhoods cooler through belts of trees and green roofs of grass on top of buildings; seeks to assess effect of hotter climate on rich and poor; will try to determine if local action can provide some relief from global warming or if large-scale government action is needed; photo (L)

Title: Connecticut Auto Emissions Inspections Found Problems That Weren't There
Abstrace: Agbar Technologies, contractor that manages Connecticut auto emissions tests, will reimburse as many as 13,000 car owners who paid for unnecessary repairs after their vehicles were mistakenly found to have failed inspection because of software flaw; will hire outside auditor to examine testing equipment and will arrange for outside oversight (M)

Title: Touchy Subject of Tolls Is Back in Connecticut
Abstrace: With Connecticut unable to afford the extensive repairs needed for its roads or upgrades to its mass transit system, some state officials are pushing for tolls.

Title: A Mercury Warning Is Issued
Abstrace: Connecticut Departments of Environmental Protection and Public Health post signs around state warning anglers about high levels of mercury in fish and cautioning them to limit amount of fish they eat; photo (M)

Title: Housatonic River Ranked Among Most Endangered
Abstrace: American Rivers, conservation group, places Housatonic River, which flows through Connecticut to Long Island Sound from Massachusetts border, seventh on its list of 10 most endangered rivers in United States; cites critical decisions that are expected to be made in coming months about cleaning up toxic PCB's downriver from old General Electric transformer factory in Pittsfield, Mass; map (M)

Title: The Price We Pay for Heading South Each Morning
Abstrace: Jack Kadden Commuter's Journal on upcoming fare increase on Metro North commuters in Connecticut, which some experts say will increase road traffic and air pollution; drawing (M)

Title: Ban on Cables in L.I. Sound Is Sent to Rowland
Abstrace: Connecticut Senate overwhelmingly approves bill placing one-year ban on construction of power or gas lines across Long Island Sound; Gov John G Rowland has expressed reservations about signing bill (M)

Title: Move Again? Not This Time.
Abstrace: Article on vow by 81-year-old homeowner Sylvester Salemme not to budge if Connecticut Department of Transportation decides to condemn his house to make way for access road for new railroad station in Orange; photo (M)

Title: Squeamish or Not, Students Help a Cause
Abstrace: Article on Project Search, program run by Connecticut Environmental Protection Department and Science Center of Connecticut in West Hartford, in which high school students check quality of water in Connecticut rivers and streams; project's goals are to provide students with hands-on science experience and have them produce usable water quality data for local, state and federal management officials; photos (M)

Title: Emissions Tests Will Resume After a Six-Month Suspension
Abstrace: Connecticut, six months after suspending its troubled auto emissions program, says that testing will resume on Nov 12, and that Agbar Technologies, company running program, has settled lawsuit against state; company has encountered persistent problems with false readings and allegations of fraud since taking over program in Oct 2003 (M)a

Title: The Battle To Get Us To Pipe Down
Abstrace: Article on noise ordinances in towns and cities throughout Connecticut, many enacted following complaints about specific noises, that are more stringent than rules adopted by State Department of Environmental Protection; state, whose law has many exceptions and exemptions, encourages municipalities to enact their own, which must be approved by DEP before taking effect; drawing; photos (L)

Title: The View From/Newtown; Over the Guardrail, The Other Side of Paradise
Abstrace: Group of neighbors who live along shore of Housatonic River in Newtown, Conn, are pushing state, which says it lacks funds, to erect wooden safety barriers along Interstate 84 guardrail; say traffic noise, pollution and car and truck tires and parts that have ejected over guardrail into residential streets and yards make road unsafe; photo (M)

Title: Hermaphrodite Frogs Found in Suburban Ponds
Abstrace: Common frogs that make their homes in suburban areas are more likely than their rural counterparts to develop the reproductive abnormalities, a new study suggests.

Title: Female Lobsters Won’t Get a Reprieve Just Yet
Abstrace: A STATE program that will pay fishermen to throw back female lobsters to help repopulate depleted stocks has been delayed indefinitely because of insurance and liability issues involving student workers.

Title: Who Is Killing Long Island Sound?
Abstrace: Connecticut turns its back on protecting our water.

Title: Next Step for Rerouting Planes May Be in Court
Abstrace: AFTER nearly nine years of study and more than a hundred public meetings, Federal Aviation Administration officials say they are weeks away from issuing a final decision on how to reroute airline flights over the region to ease bottlenecks in the sky. Communities that fear a sharp increase in the number of flights rumbling overhead are now turning to what they say is their only chance to stave off noise pollution: the courts.

Title: Who Is Killing Long Island Sound?
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by Tom Andersen scores Connecticut Legislature for backing off from its commitment to help clean up Long Island sound by slashing funds for sewage plant improvements; notes New York, on other hand, has become tortoise that might reach nitrogen reduction goal of 58.5 percent first; calls on Connecticut General Assembly to reach agreement with governor to restore Clean Water Fund (M)

Title: Study Says U.S. Companies Lag on Global Warming
Abstrace: Report by Ceres, coalition of investors and environmentalists, says European and Asian companies are paying more attention to global warming than their American counterparts; contends chemical companies are more focused on issue than oil companies; report gives chemical industry highest overall marks, with score of 51.9 out of possible 100; DuPont, with 85 points is highest-ranking American company in any of industries; airlines, in contrast, ranked lowest, with score of 16.6; UAL received 3 points; study gives General Electric, American Electric Power and Cinergy among highest scores in their industries; says American companies are playing catch-up with international competitors like BP, Toyota, Alcan, Unilever and Rio Tinto; members of Investor Network say they will take report's conclusions seriously; Connecticut Treas Denise L Nappier, who administers $22 billion investment fund, lauds report (M)

Title: Who Is Killing Long Island Sound?
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by Tom Andersen scores Connecticut Legislature for backing off from its commitment to help clean up Long Island sound by slashing funds for sewage plant improvements; notes New York, on other hand, has become tortoise that might reach nitrogen reduction goal of 58.5 percent first; calls on Connecticut General Assembly to reach agreement with governor to restore Clean Water Fund (M)

Title: Ruth Sims, First Woman Elected to Lead Greenwich, Dies at 92
Abstrace: Mrs. Sims, a Democrat in the historically Republican Connecticut town, succeeded in the 1977 race for first selectman after two recounts and a second vote.

Title: Wet Weather And Water Don't Mix
Abstrace: Article on increase in closings of beaches and swimming holes in Connecticut this summer as heavy rains raise amount of effluent flowing from sewers and storm drains; photos (L)

Title: Who Is Killing Long Island Sound?
Abstrace: Op-Ed article by Tom Andersen scores Connecticut Legislature for backing off from its commitment to help clean up Long Island sound by slashing funds for sewage plant improvements; notes New York, on other hand, has become tortoise that might reach nitrogen reduction goal of 58.5 percent first; calls on Connecticut General Assembly to reach agreement with governor to restore Clean Water Fund (M)

Title: Here We Go Again
Abstrace: Article on controversy over auto emissions testing at service stations across Connecticut; stations, which invested thousands of dollars in equipment, turned over part of their stations to Agbar Technologies of Chicago, which runs program, and hired more people to conduct tests, have laid off some workers after state suspended testing on April 22; photos (M)

Title: An Overhaul For Emissions Testing
Abstrace: Article on concerns raised as Connecticut, embarking on first major overhaul of its car emissions tests in nearly 20 years, completes contract negotiations with Agbar Technologies of Chicago; state plans to eliminate 25 centralized testing centers and allow tests at more than 300 service stations and car dealerships; photos (M)

Title: Sitting Idle: Empty Bays and Lost Profits
Abstrace: Suspension by Connecticut Department of Motor Vehicles of Agbar Technologies contract to test auto emissions is having adverse impact on owners of service stations who converted bays and installed testing equipment; service station owners and managers say they have lost the cost of their investments as well as money from customers seeking testing and repair work; photos (M)

Title: Branzino, a Mediterranean Fish, Is Being Farmed in Connecticut
Abstrace: Ideal Fish is banking on technology to provide a fresher, more sustainable source of the popular fish.

Title: Celebrating A River's Artful Revival
Abstrace: Article on day trips to events this summer celebrating revival of upper Housatonic River between Pittsfield, Mass, and New Milford, Conn; photo (M)

Title: An Accidental Canadian Finds Her Environmental Footing
Abstrace: Elizabeth May is one of Canada's most prominent environmentalists; she founded Sierra Club of Canada in 1989, and has emerged as leader of Green Party of Canada; May was born in Connecticut to affluent parents; her mother, Stephanie May, was founder of Committee for Sane Nuclear Policy; most surprising factor in Elizabeth May's ascent is that she has overcome misgivings about her American upbringing, though she did become Canadian citizen; photo (M)

Title: Warm Water Killed the Lobsters
Abstrace: Researchers, in series of reports delivered at symposium at Stony Brook University, conclude that combination of sustained high water temperatures, low levels of dissolved oxygen and toxic impact of ammonia and sulfides was cause of major lobster die-off in western Long Island Sound between September 19 and 22, 1999; die-off essentially wiped out $100 million lobster industry, idling hundreds of New York and Connecticut lobstermen; some researchers view die-off as ominous, if still tentative, sign of global warming while others are less certain about whether and to what degree pesticides contributed; photos (M)

Title: The Twists And Turns Of Pedaling To the Job
Abstrace: Melinda Tuhus article describes advantages of commuting in Connecticut by bike between her home and office (M)

Title: The Beetle That Ate the Region
Abstrace: How to stop those invasive species that kill all the trees.

Title: Congress Puts Authorization Of L. I. Cable In Energy Bill
Abstrace: Congress will vote on national energy bill, which, if passed, will include small provision ceding 24-mile electric cable crossing under Long Island Sound to New York, not Connecticut; Connecticut officials say cable, which has been channeling electricity to Long Island Power Authority since 2003 blackout, violates state environmental rules (M)

Title: At Some Superfund Sites, Toxic Legacies Linger
Abstrace: The cleanup of toxic sites in the region is not easy and frustrations often are expressed.

Title: Spinning Wheels On New Emissions Tests
Abstrace: Article on confusion among public over Connecticut's new automobile emissions program, which begins on September 19; cars 25 years or older will not require testing and models ranging from 1996 to 2000 may face alternate test; photos (M)

Title: Affordable Housing Fight Will Not Let Up
Abstrace: Article on battle over affordable housing mandated in 1989 by Connecticut General Assembly; town officials say developments put undue strain on town services, are too dense, worsen traffic and pollution problems and add too many students to beleaguered schools; proponents say affordable housing is needed now more than ever; photos (M)

Title: Harvesting Homegrown Art
Abstrace: The Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum in Connecticut is celebrating the work of local artists with a show indoors and outdoors.

Title: Wild Bullets in Vicinity of Range Catch Government Attention
Abstrace: Several gun ranges across Connecticut are being challenged by neighbors who charge safety, noise or other violations.

Title: Plan to Move Family Y Is Drawing Opposition
Abstrace: The Y.M.C.A. considers itself the heart of the community, but a plan to relocate the Westport branch is giving some in town heartburn.

Title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
Abstrace: NEW YORK.

Title: Revising the Contracting Process in Connecticut Is Proving to Be Elusive
Abstrace: Policy changes in Connecticut intended to reduce political influence in awarding of state contracts were put into place two months ago, but officials are finding problems easier to define than resolve; Atty Gen Richard Blumenthal is requiring state officials and contractors to sign affidavit disclosing gifts over past ten years; one company has given up contract rather than submit information; disclosure does not necessarily disqualify contractors but does require review of proposal for potential impropriety and could alert federal investigators of possible criminal wrongdoing; state officials say more companies are applying for state work, which Blumenthal believes is move away from 'insider bidding club'; lawmakers, preparing to codify policy, face questions about its practicality and effectiveness (M)

Title: In Connecticut’s G.O.P., a Vanquished Rival Lingers On
Abstrace: Some Republicans are questioning the endorsement of Linda E. McMahon, the wrestling impresario, for the Senate over Rob Simmons at the party convention.

Title: Connecticut Lobstermen Hope for a Reprieve
Abstrace: Long Island Sound’s ailing lobster industry won’t be getting any help this year from Connecticut’s state legislature.

Title: A Run for Governor, Rough Edges Included
Abstrace: HARTFORD.

Title: In Local Waters, an Oyster Resurgence
Abstrace: Two years after a failed effort to declare it an endangered species, the Eastern oyster is making a big comeback.

Title: Cremate Dead Horses? Why Not, Some Say
Abstrace: Two friends see a horse crematorium as a solution endorsed by many horse owners, veterinarians, state officials and others as environmentally sound and dignified.

Title: Trying to Get There From Here
Abstrace: Editorial welcomes Conn Gov M Jodi Rell's appointments to State Department of Transportation but maintains her work is not done; offers suggestions to ease congestion while I-95 around New Haven is improved and new bridge over Quinnipiac River is built

Title: Trying to Get There From Here
Abstrace: Gov. M. Jodi Rell’s appointments to the State Department of Transportation’s top three leadership positions gave Connecticut commuters a fleeting, yet alien feeling: hope.

Title: Commuting by Road, but Not by Car
Abstrace: Bus systems are attracting new riders as $3-a-gallon gas prices remain common around the region and mass-transit advocates urge commuters to leave their cars at home.

Title: Taking Time Out to Search for a Coastal Area’s Past
Abstrace: Madison.

Title: Renowned From Trunk to Treetop
Abstrace: Article on what makes some trees in Connecticut notable; focuses on Stamford Tree Foundation's recent Notable Tree Contest, which asked young children to help find notable undiscovered trees; experts comment on caring for trees and tree lifespans; photos; list (M)

Title: Using Factory Sites for Other Purposes
Abstrace: Stonington is pushing aside zoning rules that reserve the sites for manufacturing purposes and inviting developers to dream up new uses for the properties.

Title: THE VIEW/From The Quiet Corner; One Town's Rejection Is Another's 'Let's Do Business'
Abstrace: Article on rejection by conservation commission in Killingly, Conn, of zoning change that would have allowed construction of Wal-Mart distribution center; also focuses on efforts by nearby towns to persuade Wal-Mart to build there; photos (M)

Title: Residue From Industrial Past Haunts State
Abstrace: Assessment and cleanup of radium paint dropped onto floors and walls of several old clock factory buildings in Connecticut gets underway; health officials say worst problem is at former Waterbury Clock Co factory in Waterbury, part of which has been converted to apartments; photos (M)

Title: Open Space: Preserving It Takes a Village
Abstrace: FROM the banks of the Fenton River in Mansfield, a leaf-cushioned landscape rises first gently, then steeply past granite boulders, birch and maple trees, footpaths and the remnants of sheds and stonewalls to a 1,000-foot-long ledge. Hikers who reach the top are rewarded with views of Mansfield Hollow Lake and the Town of Scotland's rolling hills about 10 miles away.     In 1927, when Mansfield's landscape of fields was beginning to sprout trees as the number of farms declined, schoolchildren in a contest picked this spot as one of the places in town they would most like to see preserved.

Title: 'Lap of Luxury' in Downtown Stamford
Abstrace: BRIAN JANUSH is only 30, but he is already reaching for the pinnacle of luxury city living. A cellphone store owner who got his start selling phones at flea markets at the age of 15, Mr. Janush thought he was living ''the dream'' during the years he rented a downtown apartment at the Classic.     Two years ago, he stepped up the extravagance with the purchase of a penthouse condominium overlooking Stamford Harbor. ''I'm single, no children, so I kind of spoil myself,'' Mr. Janush said.

Title: Is This Why Gregory Peck Was So Cool?
Abstrace: Article on Italian Vespa motor scooters, made famous by Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn in movie Roman Holiday, that are beginning to appear, after 15-year absence, as chic and practical mode of transportation in Connecticut; photos (M)

Title: Several States Likely to Follow California on Car Emissions
Abstrace: California's plan for sharp cuts in automotive emissions of global warming gases could eventually lead much of coastal US to turn to vehicles that are substantially cleaner, and by extension more fuel efficient, than those in rest of nation; New Jersey, Rhode Island and Connecticut have said they intend to start following California's car rules instead of those of federal government; New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine already do so; photo (M)

Title: Conservationists Are Divided on Cross-Sound Gas Pipeline
Abstrace: Conservationist groups in Connecticut contend planned natural gas pipeline across Long Island Sound will destroy oyster and lobster habitats and fish breeding areas and endanger delicate wetlands; some Long Island conservation groups support plan, citing need for new power plants as demand for electricity continues to grow; map (M)

Title: A Mill Town Writes Its Next Chapter
Abstrace: Living In article on Georgetown, Conn; table of geographic data; map; photos (M)

Title: Connecticut Faces Fight for Senate, Inside G.O.P.
Abstrace: A fierce contest between Linda E. McMahon and Christopher Shays for the Republican nomination could damage the winner.

Title: A State Secret: Starry Nights
Abstrace: Article on area of northeastern Connecticut which, because of its rare darkness along US's densely populated Northeast coast, has become beacon for amateur astronomers; one of most popular star-viewing areas is James L Goodwin Conservation Center in Goodwin State Forest in Hampton; photos (M)

Title: Warehouses Transform N.Y.C. Neighborhoods as E-Commerce Booms
Abstrace: The region is home to the largest concentration of online shoppers in the country. The facilities, key to delivering packages on time, are reshaping neighborhoods.

Title: What the Infrastructure Bill Means for the New York Region
Abstrace: The bill, which President Biden is expected to sign Monday, is likely to fund road and bridge repairs, water infrastructure upgrades and airport expansions.

Title: The Little Town That High Prices Forgot
Abstrace: WELCOME to Derby, a small town at the confluence of the Housatonic and Naugatuck Rivers, where a dozen decrepit downtown buildings are about to be demolished.      It has been a century since Derby's industrial manufacturing heyday, town officials point out. High time, then, that the crumbled brick structures and abandoned factories are cleared out. If necessary, the town can invoke eminent domain to achieve that goal. Its plans call for as many as 700 rental apartments and condominiums, as well as 100,000 square feet of stores, restaurants and offices, and an underground parking garage topped by a park.

Title: The Little Town That High Prices Forgot
Abstrace: Welcome to Derby, a small town at the confluence of the Housatonic and Naugatuck Rivers, where a dozen decrepit downtown buildings are about to be demolished.

Title: Redrawing the Electric Power Grid
Abstrace: Central issue in power industry and among alternative power advocates is how best to eliminate bottlenecks in transmission grid: by building more long-distance transmission lines or by generating more power in small quantities close to where it is needed; aging transmission grid prevents much of power from flowing easily into areas where it is most needed during summer consumption spikes; traditional solution--to build more and bigger transmission lines--has few fans outside industry; many utility executives and regulators believe building more long-distance transmission lines and finding alternatives to long-distance transmission are both necessary; United Technologies is developing fuel cells and wants to adapt them to use with other local forms of power generation; chairman-chief executive George David comments; how Connecticut Valley Electric Exchange, or Convex, tracks movement of power in Connecticut and western Massachusetts discussed; photos (M)

Title: As Far as the Eye Can Climb, Towering Spots With History
Abstrace: Article on castles and stone towers that offer views from high points in Connecticut, including Battell Stoeckel Tower in Norfolk and Castle Craig in Meriden; photos (L)

Title: A Fall Feast From the Palette
Abstrace: Foliage is a popular excuse for an autumn outing, but artwork may run a close second. This is the time of year when museums throughout the region roll out their best stuff.

Title: Where To Gaze At the Stars All Over The State
Abstrace: Article on astronomical societies and clubs that meet at observatories and museums across Connecticut; photos (L) (Special Issue: After 5)

Title: On Back Roads, It's Stop, Chat and, Oh Yeah, Fill 'Er Up
Abstrace: Article on family-owned gas stations scattered through Connecticut's rural back roads that also serve as repair shops, country stores, antique shops and local gathering places; photos (Special Issue: Summer in Connecticut) (L)

Title: Forests in Peril
Abstrace: Forests cover nearly 60 percent of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and there is no question that they will continue to exist. But what will they look like in the future?

Title: Seeking Summer All Year
Abstrace: SUMMER is ripe in the modest seaside cottages here in Old Lyme: Soul-deep heat. Lazy lopes back to the house after a day in the sun. Porches cluttered with inflatable beach toys. Cheap charcoal grills in the grass. Italian ice. Carousel rides. A couple of rowdy bars but mostly just a gentle family tempo. And the evening light is perfect.     Naturally, when summer is over, not everyone will want to go home. The trouble, however, is that they have to, and not necessarily because they must return to school or work.

Title: Different Fight, Same Battleground
Abstrace: Article on latest rift between Connecticut and Long Island over dredging of harbors on Connecticut side of Long Island Sound and how and where to dispose of muck; federal government, after five-year study, has picked two spots, one in Noroton and other in East Haven; Army Corps of Engineers project manager Mark Habel says agency, which has range of environmentally acceptable alternatives, has chosen least costly; photos (M)

Title: Ferries in Alaska. Rail in Oregon. States Dream Big on Infrastructure Funds.
Abstrace: The infrastructure bill could reshape priorities across the country, jump-starting critical projects that stalled over funding. These are some of the possibilities.

Title: Tide of Humanity Alters Long Island Sound
Abstrace: First of summerlong series of articles on evolving nature of Long Island Sound; there has been growing realization that Long Island Sound, ancient estuary extending 110 miles northeast from New York City to Rhode Island through densest population corridor in nation, has in a very real way become a human creation, where impact of civilization is complete; people have come to realize that sound would have to be managed for its own sake, and for region's; in economics, politics, culture and science, people took action, and nature responded; tiny sea plant called eelgrass, and group of families in Groton who unitentionally triggered its resurgence, play a part in story; management of nature, called environmental stewardship, is being applied in many places around world; photos; map (L)

Title: Water Quality Is Still a Concern
Abstrace: League of Women Voters of Connecticut drinking water specialist Cheryl Dunson letter praises effort in Branford, described in August 25 article, to clean up part of Long Island Sound

Title: Not Enough Progress On Long Island Sound
Abstrace: Save the Sound director Leah Schmalz letter on Tom Andersen's September 3 Op-Ed article on Connecticut's lack of commitment to clean up Long Island Sound
